3. Once water is boiling reduce heat and add pasta. Stir stir every few minutes to make sure pasta does not stick. Cook until pasta is al dente, soft but with a bit of a bite. APPROX 7 MINUTES
4. Drain water and stir in lots of ice, stirring constantly to fully cool all pasta. Once fully cooled be sure to drain any excess water. Then add oil and stir

1) Rinse sorghum grain VERY THROUGHLY!!! in china cap strainer and water. You can make this easy by putting the strainer in a large soup pot and running the water over the sorghum until the water runs clear from the pot.
2) Add water to rinsed sorghum and bring to a rapid simmer over medium high heat. Stir every once in a while to make sure it isn't sticking to the pot.
3) When the water comes to a rapid simmer, cover with aluminium and turn to very low heat. Sorghum will take about 30-40 minutes to cook. When Sorghum is finished it will have a pleasant, chewy consistency.
4) Rinse under cold water until cool and store in appropriate vessel. Label, Date, Refrigerate.

NOTES: It's important to note that this is an opportunity for using old or slightly old Cucumber! For instance: look at the recipe for Taboulleh Salad Mix - Cucumber cores should be saved, and then processed and strained in Cheese Cloth for this recipe - otherwise it will be too watery.
In Turkey, there is a dish known as Cacic - a watery version of Tzatziki. The ingredients are more or less the same. What we know as Tzatziki is actually made with Labneh, which is pressed Yoghurt. Since we use regular Yoghurt in this recipe, we have to limit the amount of water content in it, otherwise it will be an undesirable AND low-quality product.

- THIS RECIPE IS A TOUGHT ONE; CRISPY SHALLOTS ARE AN ART FORM. PLEASE FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY, AND GET CHEF TO DO THIS WITH YOU ONCE BEFORE TRYING IT ON YOUR OWN.
- Mandoline Shallots into thin rings - Approx. 2mm.
- Created a Salt/Water Brine at 10% salt (100g Salt: 1000ml Water). Soak mandolined Shallots in Brine for 10 minutes. Rinse once with clean water, and let rest for 20 minutes.
- At 325-350F, fry Shallots until golden. Shallots will continue cooking once you take them out - and set them on a tray lined with paper towel. IMPORTANT: as soon as you take the Shallots out of the fryer, and onto their blotting surface of paper towel, you will need to move them around so that they don't clump up and form balls or nests (which, once dried, will not come apart easy). THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT TO GETTING A GOOD PRODUCT.
- Any questions (especially with this recipe, as the yield is low), PLEASE ASK CHEF!

1) Bring water to a rapid boil in an appropriate sized pot. Gently lower eggs into boiling water with a slotted spoon.
2) Cover pot with aluminum foil and turn heat off completely. Allow eggs to sit in hot water for 8-9 minutes.
3) Strain eggs, and shock in ice bath to stop eggs from cooking further and to make them easier to peel.
4) When eggs are completly cool, peel them.
5) Egg whites should be fully cooked, and yolk should be slightly runny.
6) Store in appropriate contianer. Label, date, refrigerate.

Egg

Prep:
- Take the Coriander Seeds, Cumin Seeds, Ajwain Seeds, Black Pepper and Garam Masala - and toast, then grind in the Vitamix into a fine powder. The toasting, as mentioned in other recipes, is key to developing flavour and aroma.
- Amchur Powder is not a spice, but a powder made of green mango. It should not be toasted. Opinions differ on this, but - for this recipe, do not toast this ingredient.
- Normally this recipe would be made into a paste with lemon juice and a small amount of water. We use this as a more dry rub, in combination with alread-wet ingredients like potatoes that have been boiled and chickpeas that sit in "aqua fava" (literally: bean water).
- If this spice mix is low, talk to a Chef about it. Some of these ingredients come from a specialty provider with an indented delivery schedule - and will need to be ordered several days in advance in order to allow for proper prep time.
Any questions - Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- Basically, this is a bound gel of sweetened Tamarind Paste. 1 Jar is 300g, so the recipe is built around that.
- Fresh Tamarind, which isn't very widely available here in North America, is not very tart at all like Tamarind Paste. Citric Acid, other additives, and industrial processes force it to be this way - so it needs to be let out and sweetened. Allspice in this recipe is used to mask some of the bendinf that this ingredient must go through.
- Place all ingredients into a Vitamix. Keep Xanthan Gum aside.
- Start the Vitamix, and slowly raise the speed setting until you're working with a fine mixture of all of the aforementioned ingredients. On "High" (the button to the left of the speed setting nob), remove the plunger from the pitcher base, and add the Xanthan Gum while the mixture is moving.
- You should know, with this recipe, and all recipes requiring a binder like Xanthan Gum, how a thickener is doing in its job. To test this mixture, turn the Vitamix off, and dip the plunger into the mixture, then raise it to see how slowly it falls off the plunger. It should fall slowly. If it doesn't, add more Xanthan Gum binder, and continue. The idea is that this will become like a paste that will get things dipped into it.
- Don't worry - if you thicken it too much, you can always go backwards and let it out again, easily. This is not like over-cooking a steak. That said, know what you're looking for, and do it.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...
Any questions - Ask Chef!

SEQUENCE:
1. Tortilla into bowl 2. Rice + bean 3. Salsa Verde 4. Guacamole 5. eggs 5. Arugula 6. Feta 7. Crispy Shallots
Note: as a general rule, it is best to put sauces on the Burrito right after the rice stage. If you put the sauces on last, or at the top (facing the customer) of the burrito - it will be a mess when you're done. It's a good technuique to put the cabbage, cheese, or arugula at the top of the burrito (facing the customer) before rolling it, as this will keep your hands clean, and help you save on glove waste.
SERVE IN BOWL NO WRAPING

Method: 1.Drain Cannelini Beans. The Yield on these beans has been calculated in this recipe - roughly the loss of over a Kilogram in "Aqua Fava". A quick rinse is valued, but not entirely necessary. 2.Half all Grape Tomatoes. You will notice in this recipe that 5 LBS is the measured amount require. This is because each box of Grape Tomatoes that comes in from Freshpoint is 10 LBS - meaning: use half of a box for this recipe. Easy enough? 3.Small Dice yellow Onions. Saute with Cumin and Cayenne, adding 1 Bag of Frozen Corn and Red Pepper to the mix along the way. Do not roast this Corn in the oven for any reason - its starches develop and it becomes tough texturally. Deglaze this mixture with Apple Cider Vinegar, and season.
- Pick Oregano. Don't bother picking the Cilantro, as some stem is fine in this recipe. Rough Chop both of these, and reserve to add into the rest of this recipe.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...

1. heat stock in pot over medium-high 2. heat a large rondeaux or tilt skillet and add canola oil 30 ml 3. add mushrooms and sear quickly until slightly softened, remove from head and keep for later steps 4. heat rondeaux again and add oil to cover the whole surface of it's bottom, approx 100 ml 5. add onion, garlic and onion cooking lightly 6. add all of the dry arborio string with wooden spoon to coast all the grains of rice with fat and smoked paprika 7. when grains begin to lightly color beging by adding the first 1/3rd of the hot stock to the rondeaux 8. stir/ cook liquid out until nearly dry 9. repeat adding another third and cooking until dry 10 repeat a thrid time using the last of the stock 11. season with lemon zest, salt, pepper, thyme, olive oil and the cooked mushrooms while continueing to cook 12. cook until rice is just past "al dante" 13.lay cooked rice onto a parchment covered baking sheet to cool in the fridge 14. use cooling log, store, label and rotated this item with older product correctly and diligently
